chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: This document provides an in-depth description of for users at a client site. consists of a set of modules giving your company online access to various services offered by your bank. Each module provides functions to initiate transactions and follow up with them. There are additional modules that provide enquiry, reporting and calendar management facilities.
The following modules are covered in this manual:
Your system might not have all these modules. It depends on the setup and permissions at your company.

Each module has its own chapter. giving an overview of the module followed by a detailed description of each function in the module. A function generally corresponds to a menu item. A detailed description of any Web pages (typically lists and input forms) displayed by the function is given, explaining the use of each field.
Basic concepts and terminology, and features common to all or most modules, are described in this Introduction chapter.

In every module, in every reporting popup, you can export the details of any transaction to a PDF format by clicking the button

section.title: Types of User
section.para: A system is used by two types of organisation: banks, and companies that are customers of banks. We refer to the latter as "customers" or "clients" - we use these two terms interchangeably.
We use the term "bank group" to mean a site with overriding authority over the system, such as a bank's head office.
A member of the staff of a client or bank is called a "user". A user with administrator privileges is called an "administrator".
A system has two different user interfaces: for a user at a client, and for a user at a bank or bank group.

Both interfaces have a section called System Features, containing functions for administering and configuring the system. The rest of the interface contains end-user functions. Which functions are available to a given user depends on that user's privileges.

section.title: Audience
section.para: This manual is addressed to a user at a client, and describes the end-user functions in the client user interface.

section.title: Overview
section.para: This section introduces the basic concepts and terminology used throughout .

section.title: Products and Transactions
section.para: The financial products that a bank can provide, such as letters of credit, standby letters of credit, shipping guarantees, loans, and so on, are referred to as "products".

The communications between bank and client about an individual instance of a product typically consist of a sequences of messages. For example, the communications regarding a Letter of Credit would consist of the client's initial request, the bank's formal response, possibly some free-format messages containing further discussion, and possibly some further responses from the bank.

These individual messages are called "transactions" or "transaction events". Those sent by the bank in reply to a client message are called "reporting messages" (because the bank is "reporting back" - they should not be confused with reports produced using the Report Designer module). The whole set of messages concerning one instance of a individual product is called a "file" (this represents a "file of documents" and should not be confused with the files that can be uploaded containing details of a transaction).
The initial request from the client is often called the "initiation" of the file.

section.title: System ID
section.para: When a new file is created - for example, a client user creates a new Letter of Credit request - gives it a unique reference number called its System ID. This is used throughout the system to identify it.

section.title: Permissions
section.para: Which modules you, as an individual user, have access to, and what you can do in each module, depends on permissions granted you by your company's administrator. These permissions in turn have been granted to your company by the bank.
Your permissions are often referred to as privileges, authority or authorisation. These four terms are used interchangeably.
These should not be confused with authentication, which means your login ID and password.

section.title: Workflow
section.para: Many modules in follow much the same pattern. As a client user, you send a request to the bank on behalf of your company. This might be, for example, depending on the module, a request for a Letter of Credit or a request for a drawdown on a loan. The bank replies with a message acknowledging the request, and approving or rejecting it.
You can then send further messages to the bank, discussing or amending your request.

When the bank's reply (reporting message) arrives, it is shown in the Latest Notifications list in the Events portlet on the home pages of your company's users. It has a tick if the bank has approved the transaction, and a cross if the bank has declined the transaction.
There are also functions that display lists of these transactions, so you can monitor their progress.

When you are creating a transaction, you can save it at any time , without sending it, so that you or another user can work on it later. Its status is called Draft. On some lists it is called Incomplete.

When you try to send a transaction ("submit" it), you might find that you have insufficient authority to do so - usually because you don't have the authority to handle the amount of money involved. It is then automatically saved but not sent, so that another user with greater authority can send it. This status is called Unsigned. On some lists it is called Uncontrolled.

section.title: Date and Amount Formats
section.para: When entering a date in a date field, two formats are available. You can enter it in the form DD/MM/YYYY or DDMMYY if your locale is for instance France, or in the form MM/DD/YYYY or MMDDYY if your locale is for instance the USA..

informalexample.para: For example, entering 180401 produces a display of 18/04/2001, which in a French locale corresponds to 18th April 2001.

section.para: When you enter an amount, the system automatically formats the value entered according to the currency selected. You can either enter the amount using the decimal and group delimiters of your locale (for example, respectively [,] and [space] for France, or [.] and [,] for Singapore), or directly as a series of digits.

informalexample.para: For example, 123456.00 in a Singaporean locale produces a display of 123,456.00 if the currency involved is associated with 2 decimal places.

section.title: Lists
section.para: Many functions display a page that lists relevant records. These list pages have some things in common:

listitem.para: You can enter search criteria in a group of fields at the top of the page and click Search, to make the list show only records that match these criteria. These fields represent the most important fields in the record, as do the columns in the table.
You can use wildcards in these fields. The wildcard character is an asterisk (*). You can use it anywhere in a field.

On pages where the list might be very long - for example, if there are many transactions - the list is not displayed until you have entered the search criteria and clicked Search. Enter an asterisk in any of the search fields to get the entire list.

If your company has entities defined in its profile, then a column and a search criterion field for Entity appear in addition to the columns and fields mentioned in the page's description in this document.
You can click the triangular icons in the heading of a column to sort the display on that column in ascending or descending order.
There may be a column where you can click to open the individual record for viewing or editing. These are described in the sections for the individual functions.
